Award.AwardTitle: Analytic Certification for Additively Manufacturing Parts and Processes under Uncertainty

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in additive manufacturing enable virtually unlimited design complexity and thus require far more design decisions. Moreover, increased complexity and flexibility in a system add significant amounts of uncertainty associated with the larger number of design variables. This results in significant deviations between an original design and the printed product due to current limitations in the additive manufacturing process. Accordingly, there is an increasing pressure to enable the certification of additively manufactured parts by analysis without conducting customized testing for the printed parts. This award supports scientific investigations on the behavior of additively manufactured parts at different length scales under uncertainty. The knowledge generated from this research will play a large role in the design and certification of additively manufactured parts in the context of practical engineering systems. Ultimately, the results from this research will facilitate the delivery of high-quality additively manufactured parts with predictable performance, which is critical in aerospace, medical device, and automotive industries, among others.

The goal of this research is to enable engineers to certify additively manufactured parts according to desired properties across a broad range of processes and materials. This goal will be accomplished by enhancing our knowledge on the behavior of additively manufactured parts based on advanced statistical analysis with physical experiments. Thus, the objective of this research is to understand the relationship between mechanical behavior of fabricated parts and their inherent uncertainties in geometrical deviations (e.g., stacked position and length, and surface quality), and process parameters (e.g., build orientation, layer thickness, raster angle, air gap, contour width, etc.). Various sizes and types of cellular structures will be fabricated to analyze the range of microstructures capable of being produced by fused deposition modeling. The experimental results will be correlated to geometrical deviations, process variables and their uncertainties as well as mechanical properties. Appropriate representation schemes will also be identified for uncertainty parameters of manufacturing processes and parts. These uncertainties will be used to obtain mathematical formalisms by way of stochastic expansions, which will be synthesized into a multi-level, multi-scale model that describes the behavior of fabricated parts. The obtained model can be used to accurately describe the behavior of fabricated parts at different length scales under uncertainty. Ultimately, this additional effort will identify new knowledge regarding key uncertainties in process parameters that affect the performance of additively manufactured parts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project is to enable engineers to certify additively manufactured parts with desired properties across a broad range of processes and materials. This is accomplished by enhancing the knowledge on stochastic multiscale modeling and the verification and validation processes based on physical experiments. The research objective specifically is to understand the interaction between geometrical deviations (i.e., stacked position and length and surface quality), process parameters (i.e., build orientation, layer thickness, raster angle, air gap, contour width, etc.), and corresponding mechanical properties in fabricated parts. Various sizes and types of cellular structures are fabricated as a means to analyze the range of microstructures capable of being produced by fused deposition modeling. The physical experimental results are related to process variables, as well as their mechanical properties. Appropriate representation schemes of uncertainty parameters of manufacturing processes and parts are also be identified. These uncertainties are used to obtain mathematical formalisms using stochastic expansions, and then synthesized into a multi-level multi-scale modeling framework. In addition, the physical experimental results are utilized in the verification and validation process such that the accuracy of the stochastic upscaling can be improved. This validated upscaling model can be used to identify key uncertainties in process parameters that most affect the performance of additively manufactured cellular structures. 

During the project period, a multi-level validation framework wad developed to certify additively manufactured (AM) parts. In Phase 1, testing specimens are printed using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and selective laser melting (SLM) techniques and the material characterization of the AM-fabricated parts was conducted.  Also, geometric microstructures and internal defects of the specimens are fully analyzed to capture uncertainties at different length scales. In Phase 2, the multi-scale and multivariate framework was developed to propagate uncertainties in various length scales. The developed stochastic upscaling method was able to predict the properties of AM-fabricated parts. Also, it provides a mean to identify key uncertain parameters that most significantly affect the performance of AM-fabricated parts. In Phase 3, the verification and validation (V&V) process was developed and integrated into the stochastic upscaling. The efficacy of the developed V&V process was demonstrated with the physical experimentation results from FDM and SLM testing specimen.

The developed framework can have a broad impact in manufacturing where tradeoffs between design and material properties can be explored. The inclusion of the V&V along with the uncertainty quantification under the framework of the stochastic upscaling will ensure model adequacy at each level and appropriately propagate uncertainties in different scales.  The developed framework can be expanded to most AM processes and should be able to accelerate the development and deployment of new cellular structures in practical engineering problems.  In particular, the developed framework can assure the reliable performance of AM parts in future engineering systems, while enabling reduced weight and costs. The developed framework will be generalizable to most popular AM processes including EBM, SLM, SLA, FDM, etc. 

 


Last Modified: 09/13/2018
Modified by: Seung-Kyum Choi
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this research project is to enable engineers to certify additively manufactured parts with desired properties across a broad range of processes and materials. This is accomplished by enhancing the knowledge on stochastic multiscale modeling and the verification and validation processes based on physical experiments. The research objective specifically is to understand the interaction between geometrical deviations (i.e., stacked position and length and surface quality), process parameters (i.e., build orientation, layer thickness, raster angle, air gap, contour width, etc.), and corresponding mechanical properties in fabricated parts. Various sizes and types of cellular structures are fabricated as a means to analyze the range of microstructures capable of being produced by fused deposition modeling. Appropriate representation schemes of uncertainty parameters of manufacturing processes and parts are also be identified. These uncertainties are used to obtain mathematical formalisms using stochastic expansions, and then synthesized into a multi-level multi-scale modeling framework. In addition, the physical experimental results are utilized in the verification and validation process such that the accuracy of the stochastic upscaling can be improved. This validated upscaling model can be used to identify key uncertainties in process parameters that most affect the performance of additively manufactured cellular structures. During the project period, a multi-level validation framework wad developed to certify additively manufactured (AM) parts. In Phase 1, testing specimens are printed using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and selective laser melting (SLM) techniques and the material characterization of the AM-fabricated parts was conducted. In Phase 3, the verification and validation (V&V) process was developed and integrated into the stochastic upscaling. The developed framework can have a broad impact in manufacturing where tradeoffs between design and material properties can be explored. The developed framework can be expanded to most AM processes and should be able to accelerate the development and deployment of new cellular structures in practical engineering problems. In particular, the developed framework can assure the reliable performance of AM parts in future engineering systems, while enabling reduced weight and costs. The developed framework will be generalizable to most popular AM processes including EBM, SLM, SLA, FDM, etc. Last Modified: 09/13/2018 Submitted by: Seung-Kyum Choi
